title: FBI Announces ‘New Message’ in Nancy Guthrie Disappearance, Restricts Road Access to Her Home
description: The FBI says it is knows of a new message sent to a local news outlet regarding the disappearance of Nancy Guthrie, 84, who is believed to have been kidnapped from her Tucson, Ariz., home on Sat. Jan. 31
content:
The 'Today' show host's mother, Nancy Guthrie, 84, was taken against her will from her home on Jan. 31, police said
Nathan Congleton/NBCU Photo Bank/NBCUniversal via Getty; Danielle Bacher
The FBI is acknowledging a new message tied to the disappearance of Today show host Savannah Guthrie's 84-year-old mother, Nancy Guthrie, who authorities believe was kidnapped from her Tuscon, Ariz., home last weekend.
"The FBI and Pima County Sheriff’s Department are aware of a new message regarding Nancy Guthrie," the Pima County Sheriff’s Department said in a statement to PEOPLE on Friday, Feb. 6.
"Investigators are actively inspecting the information provided in the message for its authenticity," the statement continued. "While this is one new piece of information, the FBI and the Pima County Sheriff’s Department are still asking anyone with tips to contact the FBI at 1-800-CALL-FBI. The FBI continues to offer a reward of up to $50,000 for information leading to the recovery of Nancy Guthrie and/or the arrest and conviction of anyone involved in her disappearance."
Tucson-based KOLD News/News 13 shared that it received the message earlier in the day. "13 News received a new message this morning, February 6, regarding the Nancy Guthrie disappearance," News 13 stated.
"We are not releasing details out of respect to the family," the outlet added.
KOLD News/News 13 said it forwarded the message to law enforcement along with the IP address from the initial note. The IP address is not the same IP address as the initial note, but "it appears the sender used the same type of secure server to hide their IP address," the outlet said.
"The new note contains information the senders seem to think will prove to investigators they’re the same people who sent the first note," News 13 stated.
On Friday afternoon, a large number of FBI personnel including Evidence Recovery Team and Forensics Team members, along with more than two dozen sheriffs showed up at Nancy's house, where they searched the back of the property, PEOPLE can confirm.
"We are back at the house again as part of customary investigation follow up," an FBI spokesperson tells PEOPLE. "We were planning on getting back to the house today even before that message came in."
Speaking about the large FBI presence at the property, he said, "When the FBI is involved, we bring lots of resources."
The Pima County Sheriff's Office said in a post on X that investigators were conducting a follow-up at the Guthrie home and in the surrounding area, and that the roadway in front of the home is currently restricted.
“Nobody on foot can pass the cones," a sergeant at the scene tells PEOPLE. "We need everyone out right now. This is for further investigation.”

Nancy was reported missing on Sunday, Feb. 1, by her family when she failed to show up at church.
Law enforcement launched a massive investigation into Nancy's disappearance, saying they believe the grandmother was taken against her will, Pima County Sheriff Chris Nanos said at a press conference on Tuesday, Feb. 3.
On Wednesday, Feb. 4, the Today show host, 54, her sister Annie, and her brother Camron made an emotional plea to the potential kidnapper in a video posted to Instagram, asking for the safe return of their mother.
"We need to know without a doubt that she is alive and that you have her," Savannah said in the video.
Nancy was last seen on Jan. 31 when her son-in-law, Tommaso Cioni, dropped her off at her house sometime around 9:48 p.m. after she had dinner with him and Annie at their nearby home, Nanos told The New York Times.
A trail of what appears to be blood was seen on the front steps of Nancy's home that authorities confirmed is hers.
On Wed., Feb. 4, Nanos said authorities believe Nancy is still alive.
Want to keep up with the latest crime coverage? Sign up for  PEOPLE's free True Crime newsletter for breaking crime news, ongoing trial coverage and details of intriguing unsolved cases.
Savannah has been in Arizona with her family as they wait for answers about Nancy.
In a statement on X, FBI Phoenix said, "While this is one new piece of information, the FBI and the Pima County Sheriff’s Department are still asking anyone with tips to contact the FBI at 1-800-CALL-FBI. 
"The FBI continues to offer a reward of up to $50,000 for information leading to the recovery of Nancy Guthrie and/or the arrest and conviction of anyone involved in her disappearance."

title: Sheriff Believes Nancy Guthrie 'Went to Bed' Before She Was Abducted Overnight
description: Investigators are still searching for "Today" host Savannah Guthrie's 84-year-old mom, who has been missing since Sat. Jan. 31.
content:
Investigators are still searching for "Today" host Savannah Guthrie's 84-year-old mom, who has been missing since Sat. Jan. 31
NBC; Savannah Guthrie/Instagram
Speculation about exactly what Nancy Guthrie did after she returned home on the night she vanished has mounted since the 84-year-old was reported missing over the weekend.
On Sat. Jan. 31 at 9:48 p.m., the 84-year-old mother of Today show host Savannah Guthrie, 54, returned to her Tucson, Ariz., home after having dinner with her daughter Annie and her husband at their house, Pima County Sheriff Chris Nanos said at a press conference on Thursday, Feb. 5.
Her family dropped her off and that was apparently the last time anyone saw Nancy.
"At 9:50 p.m. that garage door closes, because [at] that time we assume that Nancy's home and probably going to bed," Nanos said at the press conference.
On Friday, Feb. 6, Nanos cleared up the confusion when he told PEOPLE, "We know she had gone to bed."
In a previous interview with NBC News, Nanos said, “When you’re taken from your bed and you don’t want to go somewhere, that’s an abduction.”
But Nanos “meant that figuratively and did not mean she was literally taken from her bed,” the sheriff’s department later clarified to NBC.
After Nancy went to bed, however, authorities aren't exactly sure what she did, Nanos told PEOPLE.
"Did she get up and answer the door?" he says. "Did she get up to go to the bathroom? Did she go to get something out of the refrigerator?
"I just know that this 84-year-old mom, grandma, went to bed that night and in the morning she was missing," he says.
Pima County Sheriff's Department
From what authorities have said, there was no activity at the house until 1:47 a.m., when Nancy's doorbell camera disconnected, he said at the press conference.
At 2:12 a.m., the software from the doorbell camera detected someone, but no video is available because there was no subscription, so investigators cannot tell who or what that was at this point. "We just have no video, but we're not giving up on that," Nanos said at the press conference.
At 2:28 a.m., Nancy's pacemaker app indicated a disconnection from her phone. Nearly 40 minutes passed between the time the doorbell camera detected a person and the time Nancy's pacemaker app indicated a disconnect.
Nanos has said previously that he believes Nancy is alive.
Authorities, though, say they have no suspects at the moment.
They are looking into alleged ransom notes that were sent to various news outlets.
During the Feb. 5 press conference, FBI Phoenix Special Agent in Charge Heith Janke said one individual has been arrested for making a phony ransom demand.
Savannah and her siblings addressed their mother's possible abductors in a tearful plea video posted to Instagram on Wednesday, Feb. 4.
Want to keep up with the latest crime coverage? Sign up for  PEOPLE's free True Crime newsletter for breaking crime news, ongoing trial coverage and details of intriguing unsolved cases.
The notes included a dollar amount and two deadlines — the first at 5 p.m. on Thursday, Feb. 5 and a second for Monday, Feb. 9, if the initial demand was not met. He added that one note referenced an Apple Watch and another mentioned a floodlight, but provided "no proof of life."
Anyone with tips or leads is asked to call 1-800-CALL-FBI in addition to the Pima County Sheriff’s Department number, 520-351-4900.

title: Pamela Anderson’s Icy Blue Jacket Is the Playful Layer We Want to Wear Now Through Spring — Shop Her Look from $33
description: Pamela Anderson wore an ice blue puffer jacket with a pale blue turtleneck sweater and straight-leg jeans while on set for her new movie “Somedays.” We found similar styles at Amazon, including a puffer coat under $35 and jeans from top brands like Levi’s, Lee, and Gap. Our finds start at $15
content:
If you click on links we provide, we may receive compensation.
Trade your basic black puffer for one of these colorful picks
Welcome to The Blueprint, where we break down the celebrity looks we want to wear right now and build them back up, piece by piece.
From Pamela Anderson’s peaceful existence on Vancouver Island to her minimalist beauty routine, there’s not much of her life I don’t want to copy — and my latest fangirl moment is fashion-related. 
Anderson wore an icy blue ensemble while filming her new movie Somedays, consisting of a baby blue puffer coat, a pale blue turtleneck top, and medium-wash straight-leg jeans. Her outfit expertly demonstrated how color can transform a typically bland one into a playful statement. That’s especially the case for her cozy coat, which I most often see in more mundane shades like black and navy. 
In fact, I figured out how to replicate her look with budget-friendly styles from Amazon’s fashion department — shop the three key staples you’ll need from $15.
Anderson’s frosty blue coat makes me want to roll my eyes at the sight of my boring black puffer hanging in my closet. On my hunt for whimsy, I was pleasantly surprised to find this similar style for under $35. I personally prefer slightly cropped silhouettes like this one because they don’t hide my curves behind heavy layers. Plus, the shortened hem doesn’t negate function. 
One customer noted that the coat is “incredibly lightweight yet surprisingly warm.” Other shoppers recommend sizing up one to accommodate for thick sweaters and hoodies. 
Straight-leg jeans are more comfortable than skinny jeans and still elongate your legs — a win-win. I gravitated towards these Levi’s because they have a slim silhouette and high waistline like Anderson’s. Buyers compliment the jeans’ soft material and comfortable fit. One shopper’s highest praise was: “The waist doesn’t gap, even when I’m squatting.”
In line with the monochromatic theme, Anderson’s character layered a muted blue turtleneck under her puffer. This cotton-blend option has a fitted (but not too tight) shape, foldover neckline, and ribbed hem. “The fabric feels soft against the skin but still has enough structure to hold its shape, and the knit is thick enough to be cozy without feeling bulky,” wrote a buyer. 
More Pamela Anderson-inspired clothing below includes a blue puffer that can be easily packed and an oversized turtleneck sweater.

title: Taylor Swift Sends Message to 'Really Inspiring' Athletes During Winter Olympics 2026 Opening Ceremony
description: Musician Taylor Swift pre-recorded a message for athletes that debuted during the Milano Cortina Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony.
content:
"I hope that this is an experience that you will cherish for the rest of your life," Swift said
Taylor Swift is wishing athletes good luck ahead of the 2026 Winter Olympics.
During the Milano Cortina Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony, the pop star made a cameo and shared a touching message with the athletes.
"I just wanted to say thank you!" Swift, 36, said in pre-recorded video, wearing a Ralph Lauren Team U.S.A. Polo Bear Long Sleeve.
"Getting to learn your stories and see everything that you’ve sacrificed and all your determination and hard work and passion and everything that’s gotten you to this point where you’re so excellent at something, it’s just really inspiring," she continued.
"I am very grateful for everything you've done to get to this point in your life and grateful you brought us all along with you on this journey so that we get to watch you do this," the "Fate of Ophelia" singer concluded.
"I just hope that you have a wonderful Olympic games. Wishing you all the best of luck and a safe journey and I hope that this is an experience that you will cherish for the rest of your life."
Swift's message to the athletes came hours after she dropped her star-studded music video for "Opalite" on Spotify and Apple Music.
The video begins as a satirical commercial for an "Opalite" spray that promises instant happiness — and turns into a cameo-packed love story around unconventional connections.
In an Instagram post, Swift said that the idea for the video "crash landed into [her] imagination" while promoting her 12th album on Graham Norton's talk show back in October 2025.
"I remember thinking I got ridiculously lucky with the group I was paired with," Swift explained, mentioning the group of actors and singers, which included Cillian Murphy, Domhnall Gleeson, Greta Lee, Jodie Turner-Smith and Lewis Capaldi, as people whose work she's "admired from afar."
She also thought it "would be wild" to include her fellow guests and Norton in the video, "like a school group project, but for adults, and it isn’t mandatory."
"To my delight, everyone from the show made the effort to time travel back to the 90’s with us and help with this video," the "Cruel Summer" singer wrote. "You might even recognize some friendly faces from The Eras Tour ... I had more fun than I ever imagined - Made new friends, metaphors, and fashion choices. It was an absolute thrill to create this story and these characters."

"Opalite" was featured on her latest studio album Life of a Showgirl.
To learn more about all the Olympic and Paralympic hopefuls, come to people.com to check out ongoing coverage before, during and after the games. Watch the Milan Cortina Olympics and Paralympics, beginning Feb. 6, on NBC and Peacock.

title: Vice President JD Vance and Usha Vance Booed at 2026 Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony
description: Vice President JD Vance and second lady, Usha Vance, were booed and heckled while attending the 2026 Milan Cortina Olympics opening ceremony on Friday, Feb. 6.
content:
Meanwhile, the crowd greeted Team U.S.A. with a round of applause
Alexander NEMENOV/AFP via Getty
Vice President JD Vance was booed at the 2026 Milan Cortina Olympics opening ceremony on Friday, Feb. 6, at San Siro Stadium.
The Jumbotron showed the vice president and the second lady, Usha, as the crowd reacted to their presence. The pair was met with boos and whistles from the crowd. The crowd's reaction shifted to applause as Team U.S.A. was featured on the Jumbotron seconds later.
Vance, 41, Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Tilman Fertitta, the U.S. ambassador to Italy, are representing the U.S. on behalf of President Donald Trump at the international games. 
The reaction to Vance comes amid growing political tensions in the U.S., and the international reaction to the Trump administration’s immigration policies. 
A week before the Olympics, “sources at the U.S. Embassy in Rome” said that ICE agents would have a security role alongside other U.S. agencies present at the games, the Associated Press reported.
However, on Jan. 27, Milan Mayor Giuseppe Sala made it clear the ICE officers “are not welcome in Milan, without a doubt,” according to the BBC. ​ Additionally, on Jan. 31, hundreds of protesters demanded that ICE agents leave Italy. The protests continued on Friday, Feb. 6, ahead of the opening ceremony.
Chief of Security and Athlete Services for the U.S. Olympic & Paralympic Committee (USOPC), Nicole Deal said on Thursday, Feb 5: "I can tell you unequivocally that there are no ICE agents that are part of the Team USA delegation on the ground here in Milan,” the Independent reported.
Sending agents from various federal agencies to bolster security for diplomats on the ground at the Olympics is not unusual, according to the AP. According to the news service, the U.S. previously sent agents from the Transportation Security Administration to the 2016 Summer Olympics.
The international protests follow the shooting deaths of U.S. citizens Alex Pretti, a local Minneapolis ICU nurse, and Renee Good, a mother of three, in Minneapolis.
Amid the ongoing political tension, Vance has reiterated that he was "proud" of how the Trump administration was conducting the ongoing immigration crackdown in Minneapolis.

To learn more about all the Olympic and Paralympic hopefuls, come to people.com to check out ongoing coverage before, during and after the games. Watch the Milan Cortina Olympics and Paralympics, beginning Feb. 6, on NBC and Peacock.

title: Fitness Influencer Sanne Vloet Announces Pregnancy Loss: 'Sharing This with an Open Heart'
description: Fitness influencer Sanne Vloet has revealed she experienced a miscarriage. "Pregnancy loss is never easy…. sharing this with an open heart <3," Vloet captioned the Instagram post shared on Friday, Feb. 6. In the post, the influencer also shared a poem she wrote on Christmas Day of 2025 about her pregnancy.
content:
"Pregnancy loss is never easy," the influencer began her post
Fitness influencer Sanne Vloet has revealed she experienced pregnancy loss.
"Pregnancy loss is never easy…. sharing this with an open heart <3," Vloet captioned the Instagram post shared on Friday, Feb. 6. In the post, the influencer shared a poem she wrote on Christmas Day of 2025, written after she learned that she was pregnant.
Titled "The Test I Almost Didn't Take," the poem states, "A friend asked if we were trying again. I laughed and said, 'Not really... but also not not trying.' It lingered in my mind all day. And suddenly, almost playfully, I thought: What if I just take a test? It felt ridiculous. Only two months after a miscarriage, what were the chances? When the result appeared, I froze. Two lines. The world went silent."
The post continues, "To my biggest surprise, and the most unexpected Christmas gift, I was pregnant again!! I felt an immense amount of joy and happiness, but the thing with experiencing a loss before is that it shapes you for any future pregnancy."
"There is that quiet voice that whispers: What if? Don't celebrate too early. You never know. Still, I let myself hope: Maybe this was our rainbow baby!!" the poem concludes.
The miscarriage marks Vloet's second in just four months. In October 2025, she shared that she experienced a "silent" miscarriage.
"Probably one of the hardest things I’ve ever gone through and shared," the influencer wrote in an Instagram caption from October. "There are truly no words to describe how I feel… and no woman should ever have to experience this kind of loss. At our first scan at six weeks, we saw a tiny heartbeat, and everything looked promising. But right at eight weeks, I had a deep gut feeling that something wasn’t right."
Never miss a story — sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer​​, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.

"Sadly, I was right," she wrote at the time, alongside video clips from her initial ultrasound. "At our next scan, we discovered that the embryo had stopped growing, and my body went through a silent miscarriage. I’m sharing this because I know how common this is, yet how isolating it can feel. So many women go through this in silence, and if you’re one of them, I hope this reminds you that you’re not alone <3."

title: Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony 2026 Recap: Mariah Carey Charms the Crowd as the Games Begin
description: The 2026 Winter Olympics opening ceremony was held in Milan and Cortina on Friday, Feb. 6. PEOPLE recapped the entire night from San Siro Stadium in Milan.
content:
Team USA athletes watched as the Milan Cortina Winter Games officially kicked off
The 2026 Winter Olympics are kicked off in Italy with a grand opening ceremony.
Hundreds of athletes from all over the world were welcomed by fans at San Siro Stadium in Milan, along with auxiliary ceremonies in the sister host cities of Cortina, Livigno and the other mountain towns where the 2026 Olympics take place this February.
The opening ceremony theme was of harmony, or "armonia" in Italian, highlighting the beauty of the Italian mountains and the chic city life of Milan.
Pop legend Mariah Carey performed at the start of the night, and Italian superstar Andrea Bocelli gave the final performance. Charlize Theron surprised the crowd with a message of "peace," while The White Lotus star Sabrina Impacciatore led a lively dance number.
At the end of the night, for the first time, two Olympic cauldrons were lit simultaneously — one at the Arco della Pace in Milan and another in Piazza Dibona in Cortina.
PEOPLE's team of reporters is on the ground in Milan, and shared live updates from the opening ceremony. Follow along here.
The Olympic Cauldrons Are Officially Aflame!
After more than two months of travels from Greece to Italy, the Olympic torch finally finished its journey — but for the first time in Olympic history, it ended in two spots: Milan and Cortina. In each city, the final torch bearers lit cauldrons in the shared host locations.
In the mountain town of Cortina, former Italian alpine skier Gustav Thöni — who won gold at the 1972 Sapporo Games, handed the torch to Sofia Goggia, gold medalist in downhill at the 2018 Pyongchang Games, who lit the cauldron.
Over in the city of Milan, at the Arch of Peace, alpine skiers Deborah Compagnoni and Alberto Tomba — who both won three gold medals each for Italy in the late 80's and early 90's — turned the cauldron aflame.
Charlize Theron Makes Surprise Appearance at Opening Ceremony with a Plea for 'Peace'
Alexander NEMENOV / AFP via Getty 
While Mariah Carey and Andrea Bocelli were known entities at the 2026 opening ceremony, Charlize Theron surprised the crowd with a speech asking for "peace" in the world.
Theron, who is South African, said she was sharing her words for her "beloved countryman," the late Nelson Mandela.
“Peace is not just the absence of conflict. Peace is the creation of an environment where all can flourish, regardless of race, color, creed, religion, gender, class, caste, or any other social markers of difference," Theron said. "Today, this message seems more relevant than ever. So let these Games be more than just sport. Let them be a reminder of our common humanity, our respect for one another, and a resounding call for peace everywhere.”
Andrea Bocelli Sends Chills Through the Arena as Olympic Torch Is Passed for Final Time
Alexander NEMENOV / AFP via Getty
Andrea Bocelli lit up the crowd — moments before the Olympic cauldron is officially lit. The 67-year-old Italian opera singer wowed spectators with his rendition of "Nessun Dorma," the aria from Puccini’s opera Turandot.
The piece has become Bocelli's signature since the death of Luciano Pavarotti, his former mentor.
As he sang, the Olympic torch moved between a few of the final torch bearers, including Giuseppe Bergomi and Franco Baresi, former Italian soccer players for famed football club AC Milan.
NBC's Broadcast Goes on Without Savannah Guthrie as Search for Her Mother Continues

For the first time in years, Savannah Guthrie missed the Olympics opening ceremony, which she typically commentates live from the host city. PEOPLE confirmed on Feb. 3 that the Today host would no longer be a part of the 2026 Milan Cortina Winter Olympics coverage as her mother, Nancy, remains missing.
Mary Carillo instead joined Terry Gannon in Milan to conduct NBC's broadcast, along with former Olympian Shaun White. Earlier Friday, Carillo and Gannon sent their "love and prayers" to Guthrie, who is in Arizona during the search for her mother.
"We’re certainly without a very important and beloved member of our team tonight. She is dearly missed by everybody," Gannon said during the figure skating team event broadcast.
"She’s covered so many Olympics, and she loves it. Right now, of course, Savannah and her family are in unspeakable, unfathomable pain. We know that in the U.S., her extended family is legion. Savannah, my friend, it’s the same way here," Carillo added.
The White Lotus Comes to the Milan Winter Games
Italian actress Sabrina Impacciatore — who American audiences may recognize from season two of The White Lotus — was visited by the ghosts of Winter Games past in an energetic, stylistic song and dance number called “Time Travel.”

The segment included an animated video that represented 100 years of Winter Olympics with all the color and psychedelics of an LSD trip, which then transitioned into a live stage performance. Each era, from the ‘20s to the ‘90s, was brought to life via images, rhythm and movement, including two-dimensional cut-outs and fun costumes.
Team USA Enters the Stadium to Loud Cheers — And Seemingly a Hint of Boos
Lead by flag bearers Erin Jackson, a speedskater, and bobsledder and U.S. Army Sgt. Frank Del Duca, Team USA paraded into Milan's San Siro Stadium for the opening ceremony.
Outfitted in their Ralph Lauren toggle coats and hats, U.S. stars like hockey player Laila Edwards and figure skater Isabeau Levito proudly walked around the stage to massive cheers from the crowd, many of whom are American fans.
When the camera moved to Vice President JD Vance, who is attending the Olympics with pregnant wife Usha Vance and their three children, the crowd seemed to pick up a smattering of boos mixed in with the cheers.
Several of Team USA Figure Skating's Biggest Stars Are Skipping the Opening Ceremony. Here's Why
When Team USA's Olympic stars hit the stage at the opening ceremony, many of the biggest names will be missing from the Parade of Nations. That's because four of the U.S. figure skating stars have opted to skip the ceremony to get extra rest before their events.
Ilia Malinin, Madison Chock and Evan Bates and Amber Glenn will not walk out with the rest of the team, choosing instead to focus on rest and recovery, U.S. Figure Skating confirmed to PEOPLE.
Chock, 33, and Bates, 36, competed earlier in the day, placing first in the rhythm dance team event qualifiers, and are expected to skate the free dance on Saturday evening. That's also when Malinin, 21, is set to compete in the men’s short program, and Glenn, 26, will likely perform the free skate for the team event on Sunday, Feb. 8.
The Parade of Nations Begins — With a Twist
As with every Olympics opening ceremony, Greece — the home of the first-ever Games — kicks off the Parade of Nations, when the athletes enter the stadium. But due to the spread-out nature of these Olympics, which takes place in Milan, Cortina, Livigno, Bormio, Predazzo and Tessero, the athletes won't all be at the main opening ceremony in Milan.
Several of the performers who carried the names of each country on an ice block came into Milan's San Siro Stadium alone, as the broadcast flashed to the athletes walking down a runway in one of the satellite stadiums in Cortina or Livigno.
It was a peculiar moment in San Siro, as fans cheered for countries with no athletes entering the stadium. It wasn't until Armenia walked in that the first batch of athletes arrived — where they were likely excited to see that they would get actual seats, a rarity at opening ceremonies.
Vittoria Ceretti, Leonardo DiCaprio's Girlfriend, Presents the Italian Flag
Before Italian star Laura Pausini sang her country's national anthem, model Vittoria Ceretti walked Italy's flag down the stage to Sergio Mattarella, the president of Italy.
The 27-year-old, who dates Leonardo DiCaprio, led a group of women all in shiny, red, green and white suits — a nod to Italy's flag. The suits were designed by Giorgio Armani, who died in September. He created not just these suits, but many of the costumes worn by the opening ceremony performers and the outfits for the Italian Olympians.
Mariah Carey Hits the High Notes
Though the Olympics won't come to the U.S. for another two years, American star Mariah Carey came out during the opening ceremony to sing "Volare" in Italian.
The singer, 56, sparkled in a silver gown topped off with a feathered boa, with her blonde hair in tousled waves, and segued into her own song, "Nothing Is Impossible."
"Volare," known in Italy as "Nel blu, dipinto di blu," was a major hit for Dean Martin in 1958, while "Nothing Is Impossible" is featured on Carey's latest record Here for It All, which came out in September.

Carey came out to enormous cheers from the Milan crowd, who hummed along and joyfully shouted when she hit the high notes.
Pizza Chefs, Moka Pots and the Leaning Tower of Pisa All Get the Stage
After a start filled with ancient statues in white, the opening ceremony quickly transformed into technicolor after enormous paint tubes dropped from the rafters, pouring down in cloth colors. With that, out came performers dressed in yellows, blues, reds and greens, who were shaped like different Italian inventions, from the moka pot to the Tower of Pisa.
The display is "a grand parade of characters inspired by symbolic categories of iItalian imagination and creativity: Ancient Rome, cuisine, fashion, literature, the renaissance, architecture, design and the Venice Carnival as well," the commentators on Eurosport explained.
A Message to the World from Milan: Harmony
The word of the night in Italy is "Armonia," or, in English, harmony. According to the official Olympics site, armonia is "a deeply Italian value carrying a powerful and universal message of peace, unity and dialogue."
The hope, said opening ceremony creative lead Mario Balich, is that the night will provoke emotional moments that will be remembered long after the Games end.
“It is about people, emotion and humanity. In a complex world, we want to offer a message of harmony, beauty and peace that can be understood by everyone.”
How to Watch the Opening Ceremony Live
This year, the opening ceremony kicks off at 8 p.m. Milan time, or 2 p.m. ET — helpful for Americans looking for something to watch during the Friday workday. The ceremony will air live on NBC and stream on Peacock, NBCOlympics.com, NBC.com, the NBC app and the NBC Sports app. NBC will run the broadcast again in primetime, at 8 p.m. ET.
What to Know About the 2026 Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony
In just a few minutes the 2026 Winter Olympics opening ceremony will officially kick off the Games from four different cities: Milan, Predazzo, Livigno and Cortina d'Ampezzo, on Friday, Feb. 6.
For the first time ever, the opening ceremony will include the lighting of not one but two cauldrons. The tradition will take place simultaneously in Milan at the Arco della Pace and in Cortina d’Ampezzo at Piazza Dibona.
While this is the official start of the Games, several events started two days earlier, including snowboarding, hockey, curling and figure skating.

title: Charlize Theron Makes Surprise Appearance at 2026 Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony to Deliver a Message of Hope
description: Charlize Theron made a surprise appearance at the 2026 Winter Olympics opening ceremony in Milan on Feb. 6. She delivered a message of hope inspired by fellow South African Nelson Mandela.
content:
The actress is a peace ambassador for the United Nations
Alexander NEMENOV / AFP via Getty 
The 2026 Winter Olympics opening ceremony wrapped up in Milan with a surprise appearance from none other than Charlize Theron.
The South African-born actress, 50, appeared in her official capacity as a peace ambassador for the United Nations to deliver a message of hope inspired by Nelson Mandela to the crowd at San Siro Stadium on Friday, Feb. 6.
“Athletes, spectators from every corner of the world, this is a message of peace by my beloved countryman Nelson Mandela,” she said. “Peace is not just the absence of conflict. Peace is the creation of an environment where all can flourish, regardless of race, color, creed, religion, gender, class, caste, or any other social markers of difference.”
She continued, “Today, this message seems more relevant than ever. So let these Games be more than just sport. Let them be a reminder of our common humanity, our respect for one another, and a resounding call for peace everywhere.”
Theron stood on stage near a dove symbol; opening ceremony protocol for Olympic Games calls for a symbolic release of doves after the Parade of Athletes and before the lighting of the Olympic cauldron. The Games stopped using real birds in 1992, and now just use the symbol.
In November, the UN Member States adopted the Olympic Truce Resolution for the 2026 Games, which ensures safe passage for athletes and officials to attend the Olympics and pushes the Games to promote and strengthen a culture of peace in their communities.
Theron — who lived in Milan for a year as a teenager — was not the only famous face to take the stage during the opening ceremony. Mariah Carey performed two songs earlier in the night, and Andrea Bocelli sang just before the actress appeared. The White Lotus star Sabrina Impacciatore also appeared in a segment that paid tribute to the history of the Winter Games.
To learn more about all the Olympic and Paralympic hopefuls, come to people.com to check out ongoing coverage before, during and after the games. Watch the Milan Cortina Olympics and Paralympics, beginning Feb. 6, on NBC and Peacock.

title: The Best Photos from the 2026 Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony in Milan
description: The 2026 Winter Olympics kicked off with a grand opening ceremony in Milan on Feb. 6 with appearances by Mariah Carey, Vittoria Ceretti and all the delegations competing. See the most eye-catching photos here
content:
On Feb. 6, the 2026 games started with a performance by Mariah Carey, an appearance by Vittoria Ceretti and more
Michael Kappeler/picture alliance via Getty
The 2026 Winter Olympics have officially begun!
Held in Milan, the 2026 games will bring together the world's top athletes in sports like figure skating, snowboarding, skiing and more for two and a half weeks. On Feb. 6, a grand opening ceremony kicked off the international athletic event, featuring plenty of sparkle and spectacle.
Ahead, see the best photos from the opening ceremony, including Mariah Carey performing "Volare" and her song "Nothing Is Impossible" and Vittoria Ceretti handing off the Italian flag.
Two dancers portraying the Roman mythological figures Cupid and Psyche lead a tribute to Italian beauty at the beginning of the ceremony.
Michael Kappeler/picture alliance via Getty
The show bursts into color as dancers perform under the ceremony's theme of "Armonia."
Italian actress and singer Matilda De Angelis, who stars in the upcoming remake of Dracula, conducts performers dressed in black and white from head to toe.
Actors donning bright monochromatic costumes parade around the stage in an orderly fashion.
Fabrizio Carabelli/PA Images via Getty
Performers created a spectacle in rainbow-colored ensembles.
Mariah Carey covers the classic Italian song "Volare" and sings her 2025 song "Nothing Is Impossible" to a sea of lights.
Fabrizio Carabelli/PA Images via Getty
Performers gave a nod to Italy's rich history of classical music.
As the trademark Olympic rings start to form, aerialists take to the skies for an airborne performance.
The iconic five rings of the Olympics shoot out fireworks.
Italian singer-songwriter Laura Pausini performs the national anthem.
Italian model Vittoria Ceretti, who is currently dating Oscar winner Leonardo DiCaprio, walks the Italian flag down the stage...
...to give to a member of the Corazzieri.
Freestyle skiers Marielle Thompson and Mikaël Kingsbury carry the Canadian flag as the team — the second-largest this Olympics — enters.
Piero CRUCIATTI / AFP via Getty
Team USA, led by gold medal-winning speed skater Erin Jackson, arrives with its largest crew of Winter Olympians ever.
The Paper and White Lotus star Sabrina Impacciatore leads a group of dancers in a routine paying homage to the Winter Olympics' history on its 100th year.
Legendary Italian singer Andrea Bocelli brings the house down with the aria "Nessum Dorma" while two torchbearers carried the Olympic flame.
Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times via Getty
Italian rapper Ghali takes the stage to recite a poem accompanied by dancers.
UN Peace Ambassador Charlize Theron gives a speech inspired by South African leader Nelson Mandela.
"Peace is not just the absence of conflict," the actress said. "Peace is the creation of an environment where all can flourish, regardless of race, colour, creed, religion, gender, class, caste or any other social markers of difference.”
Retired alpine skiers Deborah Compagnoni and Alberto Tomba help light one of the Olympic cauldrons in Milan...
Stefano RELLANDINI / POOL / AFP via Getty
...while 2018 Olympic gold medalist Sofia Goggia lights the second cauldron in Cortina d'Ampezzo in northern Italy.

title: Vittoria Ceretti, Leonardo DiCaprio’s Model Girlfriend, Brings Out the Italian Flag at the 2026 Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony
description: Vittoria Ceretti, Leonardo DiCaprio's model girlfriend, handed off the Italian flag during the 2026 Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony in Milan on Feb. 6, 2026.
content:
Ceretti wore a custom-made Armani Privé dress at the ceremony in Milan, Italy
Vittoria Ceretti brought a chic moment to the Winter Olympics in Milan.
The 27-year-old model, who is dating Leonardo DiCaprio, was among those who had the honor of serving as a flagbearer in the 2026 Olympic opening ceremony.
Ceretti, a native of Brescia, Italy, just 90 minutes away from Milan, handed off the Italian flag to the Italian Carabinieri’s honour guard, the Corazzieri, during the ceremony on Friday, Feb. 6 at the San Siro Stadium in Milan, Italy.
Ceretti, who has been linked romantically to DiCaprio, 51, for more than two years, appeared at the end of a long line of others in white, red and green suits representing the Italian flag.
The model wore a long, white, custom-made Armani Privé dress, according to Vogue Italia, with dramatic long sleeves and a high neck as she delivered the Italian flag shortly after pop legend Mariah Carey's performance.
Fans watching the ceremony were excited to see Ceretti during the Olympic ceremony in her home country. One viewer complimented the model's "dreamlike refinement of beauty and elegance" while others celebrated her "mainstream turnaround" following her relationship with DiCaprio.

Another noticed that broadcasters referenced Ceretti's relationship with DiCaprio during the ceremony, calling her boyfriend a "very, very famous actor."

Ceretti and DiCaprio have been linked for nearly three years. They were first spotted together in a video obtained by Page Six at the time, dancing together at a nightclub in Ibiza before sharing a kiss.
They were photographed together again in August 2024 during a trip to Italy with DiCaprio's close friend Tobey Maguire and others. While swimming in Sardinia, DiCaprio appeared to suffer a jellyfish sting, and in the photos, Ceretti seemed to come to his aid along with one of their yacht's crew members.
Ceretti joined DiCaprio at the Met Gala in May 2025, though the couple did not pose for photos together on the red carpet at the event. However, the actor could be seen in a photo obtained by Vogue, standing in the background and covering his face as Ceretti took center stage.
And in September, Ceretti stepped out to support DiCaprio at the premiere of his film One Battle After Another in Los Angeles, but once again skipped joining her beau on the red carpet.
In 2024, a source told PEOPLE DiCaprio "seems to really like her" and called her "very cute, sweet and charming."

To learn more about all the Olympic and Paralympic hopefuls, come to people.com to check out ongoing coverage before, during and after the games. Watch the Milan Cortina Olympics and Paralympics, beginning Feb. 6, on NBC and Peacock.

title: Newly Engaged Halle Berry Appears on The Tonight Show in New York City, Plus Succession, Ciara, Russell Wilson and More
description: Newly-engaged Halle Berry appears on 'The Tonight Show' in New York City, plus a 'Succession' reunion, Ciara with Russell Wilson and more. From New York City to Australia, and everywhere in between, see what your favorite stars are up to.
content:
From New York City to Australia, and everywhere in between, see what your favorite stars are up to
Celebrities have been everywhere this week. In New York City, Halle Berry reveals her engagement to longtime partner Van Hunt on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon. Meanwhile, over in Australia, Succession stars Sarah Snook and Brian Cox attend the 2026 AACTA Awards, and in San Francisco, husband and wife Ciara and Russell Wilson walk the carpet at the 15th Annual NFL Honors. In London, Prince William and Kate Middleton meet with the Archbishop of Canterbury, Dame Sarah Mullally.

title: A Nurse Who Works Long Shifts Doesn't Have 'Tired' Feet Thanks to These Skechers Sneakers — on Sale for $45
description: The best shoes for nurses are on sale at Amazon, including comfortable sneakers from New Balance, Skechers, Puma, Brooks, and more. . Shop the best deals on nurse-approved sneakers while prices start at $37
content:
If you click on links we provide, we may receive compensation.
Wear these shoes for long hours on your feet
If you spend long hours on your feet every day, you know how essential it is to have comfy sneakers in your rotation.
Medical professionals experience this daily, which is why we trust them to recommend Amazon’s most comfortable sneakers. Whether you work 12-hour shifts on your feet or are simply trying to get more steps in this year, these nurse-approved shoes will keep your feet from feeling sore and tired. Even better, they’re from brands like Skechers, New Balance, and Brooks and are all on sale at Amazon, with prices starting at just $37.
Thanks to these Skechers sneakers, a “very busy” nurse wrote that they don’t have “ tired, burning feet” at the end of the work day. The shoes come in a range of fun color combinations and sizes 5–16, including half sizes and wide widths.
These Under Armour shoes feature a breathable mesh upper, grippy rubber outsole, and quick slip-on design. They’ve received more than 19,000 perfect ratings, including several from nurses who praise the sneakers for being “lightweight” and “comfortable,” even after 12-hour shifts.
Not only do these New Balance sneakers lean into the “dad shoes” trend, but they’re also equipped with lightweight cushioning for all-day comfort. A nursing student referred to them as their “new favorite daily shoes,” noting how they add a little height, require zero break-in time, and are “padded enough for… 12-hour shifts.”
Several nurses and healthcare workers have praised these shoes for their unrelenting support. They have a roomy toe box, responsive cushioning, and a breathable mesh upper to keep your feet cool as you go about your busy day.
Designed to be slip-resistant and breathable, these sneakers are the perfect choice for healthcare workers, chefs, cashiers, and more. “I have spent hundreds of dollars on name brand shoes… to help my foot pain,” a nurse with plantar fasciitis wrote. “I never felt relief like I have with these shoes.”
Not only are these Brooks sneakers Amazon’s number-one best-selling road running shoes, but they’re a favorite among nurses, too. “These leave my feet feeling like I haven’t been on them for 12 hours,” one ER nurse assured.
These retro-inspired trainers from Puma have shock-absorption in the heel and a breathable sock liner for comfortable all-day wear. Nearly 40,000 Amazon shoppers have given them a five-star rating, including several nurses. They come in 25 color combinations at varying prices, but you can snag these black and pink ones for just $37.
“Being a nurse, I need good support being on my feet all day,” a shopper said. They went on to say these Skechers sneakers are “slip-resistant, comfortable, and great for those hard floors [because] they have a great arch.”

title: Wife of Seahawks' Drew Lock Admits Lifestyle Can Be 'Lonely,' but Says She Has Made 'Friends for Life' in Seattle (Exclusive)
description: Natalie Lock says being married to a professional athlete like Seattle Seahawks quarterback Drew Lock can be ‘lonely’ at times, but the support of other NFL wives has made it easier, especially as a mom of two, she tells PEOPLE before Super Bowl LX.
content:
“I’ve learned so much along the way from being surrounded by other NFL wives,” Natalie Lock tells PEOPLE
Life in the NFL isn’t always as glamorous as it looks, and Natalie Lock is opening up about that reality. As the wife of Seattle Seahawks quarterback Drew Lock, the 29-year-old says the lifestyle can be exciting, but also “lonely” – especially while raising two young children.
Between constant travel, new cities and time spent away from extended family, Natalie has had to learn how to build community wherever football takes them. What’s helped most, she says, is the bond she’s formed with other NFL wives and girlfriends who truly understand the experience.
“I’ve met some truly supportive and incredible women through the NFL, and I’m so grateful for the friendships I’ve built over the years,” she tells PEOPLE exclusively.
Drew's NFL journey began in 2019 – the same year he and Natalie started dating. At the time, he was selected as a second-round pick by the Denver Broncos, where he spent the first stretch of his professional career. In 2022, he was traded to the Seattle Seahawks, marking the couple’s first move to the Pacific Northwest.
After two seasons in Seattle, Drew signed with the New York Giants for the 2024 season before returning to the Seahawks in 2025. With every move came new routines, new homes and new circles to build from scratch as rosters changed.
Now back in Seattle, Natalie says she’s found a strong support system – even if the lifestyle still comes with its challenges. 
“This lifestyle can feel lonely at times, so having people around who understand it without explanation makes a big difference,” she admits. “We’re always rooting for one another, and I really love that part of it. I’ve learned so much along the way from being surrounded by other NFL wives.”
Never miss a story — sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer​​, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.
As a mom to son Layton, born in 2024, and daughter Landry, born in 2025, those friendships have been especially meaningful during this busy season of life.
This year has been particularly special, as the Seahawks’ wives and girlfriends have grown even closer during an unforgettable season. Seattle’s run to Super Bowl LX brought the group together through watch parties, travel and shared nerves.
“I will say that the bond we have this year on the Seahawks has been one of my favorite things this season,” she shares. “We’ve made friends for life and I’m so grateful.”
The Seahawks are set to face the New England Patriots in Super Bowl LX on Sunday, Feb. 8, 2026, marking a major moment for the team and its fans.
For Natalie, it’s another reminder of how quickly things can change in the NFL – and how important it is to appreciate each moment as it comes.
“This lifestyle comes with a lot of uncertainty, which has taught me how important it is to just stay present,” she emphasizes. “I try to put the rest in God’s hands and trust that whatever happens is exactly how it’s meant to happen.”
When it comes to being married to an NFL quarterback, Natalie says she’s learned valuable lessons about discipline, resilience and consistency.
“It takes incredible discipline to compete at this level, and I’m fascinated by [Drew’s] work ethic and resilience,” Natalie tells PEOPLE. “It has made me want to be my best in everything I do. I’m so grateful our kids get to grow up seeing that example firsthand. He truly is a superhero in our kids' eyes and I love that.”

title: Dive Team Rescues a Man After He Falls into Ice Before Their Eyes: ‘Right Place, Right Time’
description: The King County Sheriff’s Office Marine Unit and the Mercer Island Police Dive squad were taking part in an annual diving and ice rescue training session when they witnessed a man fall through the ice at Fish Lake in Chelan County, Wash. They quickly sprang into action.
content:
“They were about to pack up and leave when they saw a fisherman, walking back to shore, fall through the ice,” an official tells PEOPLE
A rescue mission for a man who fell through an icy lake got off to a very quick start thanks to the nearby location of a rescue team.
On Feb. 3 at Fish Lake in Chelan County, Wash., the King County Sheriff’s Office (KCSO) Marine Unit and the Mercer Island Police Dive squad were taking part in an annual diving and ice rescue training session when they witnessed the person fall into the ice.
“They were about to pack up and leave when they saw a fisherman, walking back to shore, fall through the ice,” a KCSO spokesperson told PEOPLE in a statement. “There were two people with him and the team says if they had tried to help all would have fallen through the ice.”
KCSO noted that the water and air temperature was about 35 degrees, adding that rescue personnel initially tried to use a rescue tube and then a rescue boogie board to save the man.  
“Three deputies reached him — they tried the rescue tube, but the ice was breaking all around them so they couldn’t get him onto the ice surface,” KCSO said.

The spokesperson continued, “They switched to the rescue boogie board — and then the rest of the team still on the dock was able to pull him onto the ice’s surface.”
Never miss a story — sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer​​, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.

Once rescued, the man was placed in a warm cabin, where an emergency medical technician assessed his health. 
“He was cold but okay and was able to drive home,” KCSO told PEOPLE, adding that a sergeant explained that “if they hadn’t been there and someone called 911 it likely would have taken the better part of an hour for emergency crews to arrive and plan for a rescue.”
Sgt. Rich Barton told local outlet KOMO News, “Right place, right time.”
“I mean, if we had not been there, you would have been reporting on a different outcome,” the sergeant said.

title: 3 'Panicking' Men Rescued After Falling Through Ice in Queens
description: Three 22-year-old men fell into the icy waters of Jamaica Bay in Queens, New York, on Friday, Feb. 6. They were successfully rescued and are now conscious and alert.
content:
Multiple first responders also fell in the frigid waters as they rescued the men
NYPD; Kyle Mazza/Anadolu via Getty
Multiple people were rescued from the icy waters in Queens, New York, on Friday, Feb. 6.
Around 4:15 p.m., the Fire Department of New York was alerted of three people in the Jamaica Bay waters, near 13-10 Norton Dr. in Far Rockaway, PIX11 reports.
The three men, all 22, were walking across the frozen bay until they suddenly fell in. At the time of their fall, they had walked about the length of a football field on the ice. They were all submerged in ice water at approximately 36 degrees, according to Tideschart. 
As they were “panicking,” they were “screaming for help,” witness Thomas Castro told ABC 7. 
Another witness, Aiden Gabourel, said he was yelling back at them to “calm down.” as they screamed, “ ‘Help help help help.’ ”
FDNY first responders arrived first, and one of them fell into the water while trying to reach the victims. The FDNY crew member was able to pull himself out.
"The first guy that came out of the helicopter actually needed to rescue himself," Castro said. "Because as soon as he went in the water his line that was supposed to attach himself with the guy he was rescuing, the line kinda detached itself."
The New York Police Department later arrived, and an NYPD scuba team member also fell into the water. The NYPD's aviation unit rescued the men with a helicopter. 
After nearly 40 minutes in the water, one of the victims had stopped moving before he was safely pulled out. "There was one in particular because I was zooming in with my phone and he looked like he was struggling more than the other ones," Gabourel said.
“And I could hear ‘em talking, 'Listen, just hold on, don't make any movements or whatever,' " he said, adding, "Yeah, I just thought about hypothermia.”
Each man was successfully rescued. One was taken to St. John's Episcopal Hospital in Far Rockaway, and the other two victims were transported to Mount Sinai South Nassau Hospital in Oceanside. All three are alert and conscious.
The victims’ neighbors said that the three men had been walking on the icy bay all week, despite advisement to stop. "All the neighbors tell them to stop. They don't listen. They don't listen to nobody," Castro said, according to the New York Daily News.
“Luckily, it was warm and not a day like tomorrow where it’s going to feel like negative 20 degrees,” Castro said, according to the outlet.
"Every day I drive by, I live around the corner, I see them doing it and I pull over and say look that's not a good idea, you shouldn't do that," Gabourel said, per ABC 7.
Never miss a story — sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer​​, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.
PEOPLE reached out to the FDNY and NYPD for comment.

title: 10-Year-Old Girl and Grandpa Stabbed While on Their Way to School by Carjacker: Report
description: A young girl and her 70-year-old grandfather were stabbed in a carjacking in the San Fernando Valley area of Los Angeles on Friday, Feb. 6 on their way to school. Officers responded to the scene at 10300 block of Eldora Avenue just before 8 a.m. local time on Friday. The victims were brought to a nearby hospital.
content:
The victims were brought to a hospital for treatment, and the grandfather remains hospitalized
A young girl and her 70-year-old grandfather were stabbed in an alleged carjacking in the San Fernando Valley area of Los Angeles on Friday, Feb. 6 while on their way to school.
Officers responded to the scene at 10300 block of Eldora Avenue just before 8 a.m. local time on Friday, KTLA reports, citing the Los Angeles Police Department. The victims were treated at the scene and brought to a nearby hospital, the outlet reports, citing the Los Angeles Fire Department.
The young girl was released from the hospital at 12 p.m. Friday, and the grandfather remains hospitalized after sustaining stab wounds to his neck — potentially hitting an artery, according to KTLA. The grandfather was last heard to be in stable condition, the outlet reports, citing LAPD.
ABC 7 obtained Ring camera footage from the scene, allegedly depicting the suspect, identified as Eric Avilez, attacking the people in the car. Neighbors told the outlet that Avilez had been causing a series of disturbances in the neighborhood while staying with family members next door to the victims.
"All kinds of crazy stuff," neighbor Mike Agajanyan told ABC 7. "Just your worst nightmare as a neighbor. You don't want this in your neighborhood."
The suspect's brother, Esteban Avilez, told ABC 7 the suspect "has mental issues."
The stabbing reportedly occurred when the pair were on their way to the young girl's school in the Sunland neighborhood, Fox 11 reports, citing LAPD. Residents in the neighborhood claimed they witnessed the suspect, allegedly a neighbor, run around the car and attempt to grab the girl. There were allegedly two other children in the car who made it to safety, the outlet reports, citing LAPD.
Want to keep up with the latest crime coverage? Sign up for PEOPLE's free True Crime newsletter for breaking crime news, ongoing trial coverage and details of intriguing unsolved cases.          
The suspect allegedly sped off in the car after stabbing the victims but ditched the vehicle a few miles later, per Fox 11. He was arrested at 2 p.m. but is yet to be booked and charges are yet to be filed, the outlet reports, citing LAPD.

title: 17-Year-Old Girl Missing for Months After Leaving Home to Meet a Man
description: A 17-year-old girl from California has been missing for two months ever since she is believed to have left home to meet a man. T'Neya Tovar of Hemet, Calif. was reported missing on Dec. 1, 2025, according to the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children.
content:
T'Neya Tovar was reported missing on Dec. 1, 2025, after authorities say she traveled 70 miles to meet the unknown adult male
National Center for Missing & Exploited Children
A 17-year-old girl from California has been missing for two months after authorities say she left home to meet a man.
T'Neya Tovar of Hemet, Calif. was reported missing on Dec. 1, 2025, according to the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children. "T'Neya may be in the company of an adult male. She has a tattoo on her left hand," her description on the Center's website reads.
It is currently believed that Tovar allegedly traveled 70 miles to Thermal, Calif. to meet an unidentified man, KTLA reports, citing detectives. Charro Tovar, her mother, told detectives that her daughter usually shared her location with friends and family members, but that the sharing stopped on the day of her disappearance, per the outlet.
“T’Neya, we all love and miss you so much,” her mother said in a statement obtained by KTLA. “We are thinking about you every day and will not stop searching until you are found safe. I need you to come back home to me.”
National Center for Missing & Exploited Children
The FBI and the Riverside County Sheriff's Office are handling the case, News Channel 3 reports. PEOPLE has reached out to the RCSO for further information.
Never miss a story — sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer​​, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.

Anyone who knows T'Neya’s whereabouts or has information related to her disappearance is asked to call NCMEC at 1-800-THE-LOST (1-800-843-5678) or the Riverside County Sheriff’s Office at 951-684-0911.

title: Woman Trampled to Death By the Horses She Regularly Fed, Say Police
description: A Florida woman has died after authorities believe she was trampled by horses owned by her neighbors.
content:
Investigators say her injuries were consistent with being trampled by a large animal
A Florida woman has reportedly been killed by her neighbor’s horses, the same animals she would regularly visit and feed. 
The incident happened just before 2 p.m. local time on Thursday, Feb. 5, in a field next to the Lucerne Lakeside Mobile Home Park, WFLA, Fox 13 Tampa Bay, and Tampa Free Press reported, citing the Winter Haven Police Department.
An identity for the victim had not yet been made public.
PEOPLE reached out to the Winter Haven Police Department and the Winter Haven medical examiner's office for comment, but did not immediately receive a response.
When first responders arrived at the scene, they found the woman unconscious and with visible injuries to her body consistent with being trampled by a large animal, such as a horse. 
Two horses were reportedly found within close proximity to her. 
Life-saving measures were performed by police, before Polk County EMS transported the woman to a local hospital, where she was later pronounced dead. 
"Our hearts go out to the family and friends of this beloved woman who cared so much to interact and feed these horses," Police Chief Vance Monroe said. 
Never miss a story — sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer​​, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.
"This was a terribly tragic accident, and we will pray for those she has left behind," he added. 
While speaking to others in the area, investigators learned that the woman frequently fed the horses. 
Foul play is not suspected and the owners of the two horses have been cooperating with authorities, local news stations reported, citing police.

title: Wayfair’s Under-the-Radar Storefront Is My Secret for Better Sleep — I’m Shopping These Bedtime Upgrades from $14
description: Wayfair has a secret storefront full of bedding finds for better sleep. One editor, who struggles with sleep, shared her top picks, including a cozy Eddie Bauer comforter, silk pillowcases, and cooling sheets. Prices start at $14
content:
If you click on links we provide, we may receive compensation.
Including luxurious silk pillowcases, a cozy Eddie Bauer comforter, and cooling sheets
I’m a terrible sleeper. My brain doesn’t know how to shut off when I go to bed, and I’m lucky if I get one or two hours of sleep per night. 
Though drinking copious amounts of coffee helps me function, I recently learned that updating your sleep space can improve your shut-eye. So, I’m turning to Wayfair’s under-the-radar Sounder Sleep Shop for a little sleep aid. It’s filled with cozy comforters, cooling pillows, and snuggly quilts to help me—and you—get off to dreamland faster.
Below, you’ll find my top 10 upgrades from brands like Eddie Bauer and Laura Ashley, starting at just $14. 
Your bedroom should be your personal oasis, so I’m using this Eddie Bauer comforter and the included pillow shams to boost my room’s cozy factor. Featuring brushed micro-suede on one side and snuggly faux shearling on the other, this reversible find will go a long way toward helping me relax come bedtime and stay warm during the remaining six weeks of winter. Reviewers add that it’s the “perfect weight” and “fits great on [a] bed,” with another person sharing that it’s so warm, you won’t need another blanket underneath.
Since I normally don’t get enough of it, I know sleep is a luxury in more ways than one. These thermoregulating silk pillowcases might be enough to convince my overactive mind to settle down for the night. They’re made from super-soft Mulberry silk, which shoppers say helps prevent wrinkles and tame frizzy hair. Now that’s beauty sleep I can get behind. 
In addition to being a bad sleeper, I also run hot when I go to bed. These cooling sheets should help me on both fronts. Older shoppers say they’re a “game changer for hot flashes,” while others add that they “feel unbelievably soft and silky — almost like hotel luxury bedding,” thanks to their bamboo fabric. 
Lately, I've gotten into the habit of reading at night to quiet my brain and unwind before going to sleep. I do most of this reading in the armchair that sits in the corner of my bedroom, and I am already looking forward to wrapping myself in this throw blanket while curling up with my next novel. I’m drawn to its chunky, knitted texture. It’s hypoallergenic, making it a safe choice for me and others who have sensitive skin. Shoppers add that it has a “high-end look that instantly elevates” any space, and its generous size is suitable for draping over the end of your bed.
Get a better night’s sleep by grabbing these bedding upgrades from Wayfair while they’re on sale for up to 71 percent off.

title: Doctor Dismissed 40-Year-Old's ‘Frog Throat’ for Years. Then She Had Her Entire Thyroid Removed (Exclusive)
description: A doctor dismissed one woman's concerns over a growing goiter after her thyroid testing panel came back ‘normal.’ After years of physical and mental health issues, she had to have her entire thyroid removed, only to learn she had been dealing with undiagnosed Hashimoto’s disease, an autoimmune disorder, the whole time.
content:
“I knew there was something deeper going on but [the doctor] never listened to me or my concerns,” Heather Wallace tells PEOPLE
Around May 2017, Heather Wallace began noticing swelling in her neck that resembled a goiter – a visible enlargement of the thyroid gland.
Concerned by its rapid growth and the development of a persistent cough, she went to see an endocrinologist in April 2018.
At the appointment, the doctor ran standard thyroid tests that measured both thyroxine (T4) and the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) to determine whether her thyroid was functioning properly.
When those results came back “normal,” the mother of three pushed for more thorough testing, but her request was ultimately dismissed for years. “I knew there was something deeper going on, but [the doctor] never listened to me or my concerns,” Wallace, 40, tells PEOPLE exclusively.
As the goiter continued to grow, Wallace slowly began to realize how much it was shaping her everyday life in ways she hadn’t initially connected.
Activities she once took for granted – long walks, keeping up with her children, even basic movement – left her unusually winded. At the time, she assumed she was simply out of shape, not recognizing that the strain on her body had been building for years.
“Some days I would truthfully just forget that I had a giant goiter in my neck because my body didn’t feel inflamed or bothered,” Wallace admits. “But there were other days when I would be in a flare, and my throat would feel so thick and large.”
Never miss a story — sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer​​, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.
Living with a visibly enlarged neck also meant navigating constant public attention. Strangers stared, and while Wallace understood that her case was unusual, the awareness never stopped weighing on her.
The attention became more painful when online comments turned into mockery, with people calling her “frog throat girl” and comparing her to a bullfrog.
“My mental health was definitely affected,” Wallace reveals, adding that the emotional toll often brought on bouts of depression. “I had such negative views about my looks, I felt so ugly.”
With a combination of persistent symptoms, unanswered questions and changes to her appearance, Wallace tells PEOPLE it all started to eat away at her self-esteem. “After years of trying to figure out the reason for my goiter with no avail… I felt so defeated,” she says. 
Eventually, after getting the opinion of yet another doctor, surgery became unavoidable. In December 2025, Wallace went into the operating room expecting a hemithyroidectomy, or thyroid lobectomy, believing only her right thyroid lobe would be removed. She was “heartbroken” to later learn they had to remove the entire gland.
“It was such a disappointment,” she admits. “When I woke up and found out I had lost my entire thyroid, I was so very sad.”
That sense of grief quickly turned into anger when she learned that a later biopsy of her thyroid showed signs of undiagnosed Hashimoto’s disease, an autoimmune disorder in which "immune-system cells lead to the death of the thyroid's hormone-producing cells," per the Mayo Clinic.
“I had spent years seeing doctors and never once did any of them test for Hashimoto’s until now,” Wallace shares. “I just wish I would have known this from the start so I could have taken care of myself in ways I didn’t know I should have because I didn’t know I had autoimmune issues until it was too late.”
Two months after the surgery, Wallace says life without a thyroid has stabilized. Medication adjustments have helped ease the side effects of an initially high hormone dose, and her body is responding well.
Emotionally, the process has been more complicated. She is still working through the weight of losing a vital organ and relying on daily medication to survive.
Over time, however, her relationship with her body has shifted in a surprising way. Without the goiter, Wallace says she feels more at home in her own skin than she has in nearly a decade.
“Once I got [the goiter] removed, I was finally able to wear necklaces again after eight years, I finally had a stronger jawline again, and I can hug my family without my neck getting squished between us,” she explains. “I think finally looking like the woman I was when I married my husband 10 years ago has really helped rebuild my confidence.”
Today, Wallace hopes her experience encourages others to trust themselves when something in their body feels off.
“Advocate for yourself,” she warns – urging patients to ask questions, seek support and push for thorough testing.
For those living with visible medical conditions, she emphasizes that judgment does not define worth.
“You have a purpose in this life and you can change so many people's lives because of the issues you have to face on a daily basis,” Wallace tells PEOPLE. “Let your heart shine brighter than the dark world around you.”

title: Woman in Her 40s, Who Says She's Often Mistaken for Being Almost 2 Decades Younger, Reveals Her Beauty Secrets
description: A woman in her 40s says she is mistaken for being almost two decades younger than she actually is. Jessica Jerrard — a former model who now works in cybersecurity — will get hit on by younger guys and will 'sometimes get ID'd' while 'buying some wine or a vape.'
content:
"People are often saying they can't believe [my age], and they think I'm 10 or 15 years younger," Jessica Jerrard said
Nicholas Rice is a Senior News Editor, Weekends for PEOPLE Magazine. He began working with the brand as an Editorial Intern in early 2020, before later transitioning to staff positions. Nicholas writes and edits multiple stories per day on average for PEOPLE, spanning across each vertical the brand covers.
A woman in her 40s says she is mistaken for being almost two decades younger than she actually is — and she doesn't mind.
"People are often saying they can't believe [my age], and they think I'm 10 or 15 years younger," Jessica Jerrard said, per SWNS.
"My kids are still young, so I don't get sister comparisons, but on work nights out, people just assume I'm the same age as my colleagues, and they get a bit freaked out when I reveal how old I am," she added.
Jerrard — a former model who now works in cybersecurity — also said she will get hit on by younger guys, including men in their 20s, and will "sometimes get ID'd" while "buying some wine or a vape."
"I've had it in the last five years. It is nice when you do," she admitted.
Never miss a story — sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer​​, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.

Looking back at her life, Jerrard said, "When I was younger, I thought 40 was really old."
The mom of two added that "it does feel good" when people think she's younger than she is, but there's also "a pressure."
The PEOPLE Puzzler crossword is here! How quickly can you solve it? Play now!
In addition to maintaining an exercise regimen, Jerrard said her youthful look can also be credited to how she has adjusted her skincare routine.
"When lip fillers started getting popular 15 years ago, I think it was about getting bigger lips, and you want more and more, but I think it just does make you look older," she said. "I used to get my lips done nearly every month, and because you're seeing it every day, it's like an addiction, and then it migrates to other areas of the face. It's not what I recommend."

Another cause of concern, according to Jerrard? Tanning.
"I used to really be into tanning when I was younger, and I was always told how bad they were, but in the past five years, I've noticed the texture of my skin not looking as good as it used to," she explained.
After trying "loads of things," including "micro-needling," Jerrard said, "I've been putting more of my investment in skin care in facials, and that's been great. It is something that I want to maintain."
And when it comes to one specific product that has been her saving grace, Jerrard credits a "Tretinoin prescription cream."
"It's made a huge difference," she said.

title: Pottery Barn’s Under-the-Radar Outlet Is Chock-Full of Deeply Discounted Furniture — Up to $1,649 Off
description: Pottery Barn has a hidden outlet section overflowing with bedding, décor, and more, but the nine best deals of the day are furniture pieces with discounts up to 70 percent off. We rounded up a sofa, coffee table, patio furniture, a nightstand, and more can’t-miss Pottery Barn furniture deals
content:
If you click on links we provide, we may receive compensation.
Including sofas, coffee tables, and patio picks
Yes, Pottery Barn has a hidden outlet. And you don’t even need to leave the couch to shop from it — the little-known deal hub is hiding in plain sight on the brand’s site. 
As the PEOPLE shopping team’s resident Pottery Barn expert, I browse the outlet regularly for discounts, and I’m always most impressed by the furniture selection. Case in point: You can currently score pieces for every room in the house (plus the patio) and expect to take up to $1,649 or 70 percent off your purchases. Shop my top Pottery Barn outlet furniture picks below, or try your own hand at hunting deals on pieces to perfectly complement your home’s aesthetic. 
This versatile console table can shine in any room. Picture it as an entryway catch-all for keys and mail, a blank canvas for displaying lamps, books, and knick-knacks in the living room, or the ideal buffet serving table for your next dinner gathering.  
It has a durable tempered glass top and a lower shelf that, together, can accommodate up to 200 pounds, and a steel frame with a classic antique brass finish. 
When it comes to living room furniture, no piece is more crucial than a sofa that’s actually comfortable and cute to look at. This one checks both of those boxes and even features a clever bench cushion that leaves no one stranded in an uncomfortable crack. Plus, said bench is nearly 6 feet long, so it can accommodate a crowd and provide ample room to stretch out for cat naps. 
The sofa is also covered in easy-to-clean performance fabric that makes it a great pick for busy households with kids or pets. 
Punxsutawney Phil may have predicted an extended winter, but it’s not too early to daydream about basking in the warmth of spring — or prepping your patio for prime porch-sitting season. In fact, as the weather warms, patio furniture prices will only rise with demand, so you won’t want to miss this last-minute off-season deal. 
The all-weather wicker lounge chair sits on a base that swivels 360 degrees and is fitted with (again, actually comfortable) water-repellent cushions. 
Pottery Barn’s best outlet deals never last long, so snap up your favorites before they’re gone for good. Then keep scrolling to shop more furniture deals hiding in the hub.

title: Student, 20, Allegedly Died After Being Trapped When Tesla Crashed and Caught Fire. Now, His Family Is Suing
description: The family of a 20-year-old Syracuse University student, who allegedly died after being trapped in his burning Tesla when it crashed last October, has filed a wrongful death lawsuit against the electric car maker.
content:
“Help please … I am going to die,” said Samuel Tremblett in a 911 call, a lawsuit his family filed on Feb. 4 claims
The mother of a 20-year-old Syracuse University student, who allegedly died after being trapped in his burning Tesla when it crashed last October, has filed a wrongful death lawsuit against the electric car maker. 
In the complaint filed in U.S. District Court in Massachusetts on Wednesday, Feb. 4, Samuel Tremblett’s mother, Jacquelyn Tremblett, alleged that Tesla designed and manufactured a “defective” 2021 Model Y vehicle that, following a collision, erupted in flames and trapped her son inside, “where he sustained catastrophic thermal injuries, smoke inhalation, causing his death.” 
According to the court document, which PEOPLE obtained, Tremblett’s mother alleges that Tremblett was driving the Model Y on Oct. 29 at around 1 a.m. local time on the northbound lane of Turnpike Street in Easton, Mass. After entering Easton, the vehicle left its lane of travel, crossed the southbound lane and crashed into a tree. The complaint added that Tremblett survived the collision. 

Immediately after the Model Y struck the tree, the complaint claims, the vehicle erupted in flames. The family alleged that due to the “defective and unreasonably dangerous electronic system for operating the door handles,” which the suit said Tesla designed, built and sold, Tremblett was unable to escape from the burning car. 
Mark Leong for The Washington Post via Getty
Never miss a story — sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer​​, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.  
The complaint mentioned an alleged 911 call Tremblett placed with a dispatcher, explaining that he was trapped in the Model Y. 
“I can’t breathe .. it’s on fire. Help please ... I am going to die,” Tremblett said, the complaint alleges. “I’m dying ... Help ... Help.’’
Police immediately arrived at the scene but were unable to extinguish the fire or remove Tremblett from the car, the complaint read. Officers said they heard four explosions in the first 10 minutes of being on the scene, per allegations in the complaint, which claimed that it took four hours for authorities to finally put out the flames. 
“Unable to open the doors, Mr. Tremblett was trapped in the Tesla vehicle and died from thermal injuries and smoke inhalation before he was rescued,” the complaint claims
The suit also mentioned at least 15 alleged incidents since 2016, in which people have died after being trapped in Tesla vehicles by the electric doors. 
“Notwithstanding the advice of Tesla’s engineers that this design was a serious safety hazard,” the complaint alleges, “Mr. [Elon] Musk [Tesla founder] refused to approve a safe, alternative design.”
“Tesla continues to manufacture and sell its vehicles with the defective and unreasonably dangerous automated door handles,” the complaint further alleged.
Among the claims by Tremblett’s family in their lawsuit against Tesla are negligence, breach of warranty, wrongful death and conscious pain and suffering. 
An obituary said Tremblett was born in Middleborough, Mass., and attended Syracuse University for three years, majoring in design studies. 
“Samuel was full of life and energy,” the tribute read. “He loved spending time with his younger brother, Tristan, whether shooting hoops, hanging out with friends, or just enjoying each other's company. 
“He was an entrepreneur who had a vision to design his own clothes and in 2024 launched his own clothing line, Forget Raven, which became an instant success, and he was preparing to take that dream to the next level," the obituary added. “He also found joy and confidence in modeling, expressing his individuality through art and style.”
“Samuel's life, though far too short, was filled with creativity, love, and light,” the tribute further stated. “His family and friends will remember his bright smile, adventurous spirit, and the warmth he brought to every moment.”
Samuel's mother dhared a statement in a news release about her lawsuit against Tesla. 
“How could Tesla keep selling vehicles that they know trap people inside their cars after a crash?” Jacquelyn claimed. “They could have fixed it, but they refused. Now my son is dead after suffering unmercifully. The people who did this must face consequences and the public needs to know how dangerous Tesla vehicles are in a crash.”
Tesla did not respond to PEOPLE's request for comment.
